title: Do I need to pay the account that's 'closed at credit grantor's request'?
question: i've now settled all my debts except for a smaller debt (under 1k) that's noted as 'account closed at credit grantor's request'. This is more than 5-6yr old debt, and is time-barred debt. Should I ignore it, or is it better to search and find out who to pay at this point, and make sure to pay since i've settled the other ones also?
answers:
I recommend against paying this time barred debt which has been closed at grantor's request". Weigh possible benefits against detriments:
-favorable reporting on credit reports
-cost of payment
-re-opening statutory collection period
-abandoning protections against collection efforts

I agree with Mr. Stempler. I would not pay it or waste my time. In another year or so it will fall off your credit report.

In addition there is no guaranty that if you track down whoever claims to own it, that some other dude will pop up and claim not only is it owed, but because you paid the wrong one, you intended to waive the SOL.

Debtors don't need to pay anything for time barred debts. Payment risks being misinterpreted as reviving the statute of limitations, even though it likely does not under California law. The SOL for debts in California is four years, but this debt may have a longer period in other states. If the debt collector threatens to sue on a time barred debt, the threat may violate the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act if it is on a consumer debt.

A recent "paid collection" may hurt your credit score more than a very old, unpaid collection account. The item will go off your credit after about 7 years; it must be removed after 7 1/2 years. Check your credit with each of the 3 agencies to see how this is being reported. Take special note of the date of the alleged delinquency. You can get each of your credit reports for free, one time each year, and annualcreditreport.com. Avoid the links that want to sell you some sort of service, and just follow the links to the credit reports that are truly free.

You can also dispute with the credit reporting agency, any debt that you wish to dispute. The credit reporting agency is supposed to "investigate" by getting confirmation from the reporting creditor. If the creditor does not respond to the inquiry, the credit reporting agency will remove the item.
